Description: Body sherd of Attic red-figured pottery stemless cup with lip offset inside; interior glazed black; exterior: red-figure decoration consisting of part of falling or recoiling warrior (corslet with brown dots on belt, shield with dentral compass point, right arm remaining); at right, part of handle palmette; relief-contour except for petals of palmette.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

The sherd possibly belongs to the same vase as British Museum 1888,0601.602 and 1900,0214.9. Beazley (CVA Oxford I, 13, pl. 14, 24) notes that the style recalls the latest manifestations of the school of Douris, such as the work of the painter of the Munich cup 2660.
Bibliographic references: Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p. 507, no. C64)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.0687) (Phase 1)
CVA Oxford I / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum Great Britain Fasc. 3, Oxford Fasc. 1 (p. 13, pl. XIV, no. 24)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford
